reviewText: Unlike the words "Restored and Remastered", Uncut (as in no censorship or edits of any kind) has a fixed meaning in the home video/DVD market. And the Fact that The Ren and Stimpy DVD is edited (even though the Box has the word UNCUT in big bold letters) is not only false advertising, it shows that John K. has absolutley no intregrity and doesn't care about his cartoons. John K. thought the edited spike Tv transfers as uncut? No, he's just trying to appease the stone-faced Viacom execs and churn out more of the schlock he has made ever sicne the original R&S.; This is aboslutley nothing like George Lucas's updated Star Wars trilogy, it's exactly what the Walt Disney Treasures would be like if they had Disney Channel Edits, or the Looney Tunes Golden Collection if it had Cartoon Network edits, or the Simpsons Box Sets if it had syndication edits. And Unlike The unintentionally edited Tom and Jerry set, which Warner Bros. is currently trying to correct, John K. basically called his biggest fans (the ones who reasonably complained about the edits) ingrates, and refused to do anything about the edits on the set (He blamed Niceklodeon for them, when in fact Nickelodeon had nothing to do with most of them).I think this is probably the worst excuse of a box set to ever be produced, even worse than Disney's Fantasia DVD. I am not going to be ripped off by some hack cartoonist whose whole career is based on 1 and a half seasons of a 13-year-old show, yet has an ego large enough to think he's better than Famed Comic Book Artist Carl Barks.In Short: Bonus Features or not, this poor excuse for a DVD is not worth it.
summary: John K. has officially lost it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I actually didn't buy Ren and Stimpy off Amazon. I bought all 3 at Wal*Mart many years before discovering Amazon. I was not disappointed. The show is as entertaining now as it was when I was little. I've picked up on jokes and stuff I never noticed before. For those who don't know, Ren and Stimpy is an old 90's cartoon that starred a chihaha named Ren and his dumb side kick Stimpy the cat. The show was insane! It had gross humor, cartoon violents, and many mind tripping moments that had kids laughing and sometimes on edge. this was during a time where cartoons both appealed to adults and children so don't be surprised if you parents out there pick up on content your children may or may not get. This first season is a little bit of an eye sore, but just keep in mind that these are some of the very first episodes. Its not until the late season 2 that the animation begins to become more artful. Ren and Stimpy is a very entertaining and fun show. There was no other kids show out there like it at the time. It had the balls to go where many kids cartoons today would never go. You have never lived through the 90's unless you've watched this show. Its worth a buy.NOTE!!!: I must warn parents that the commentaries for episodes of the show contain strong language. If you don't want your kids to hear cursing don't turn on the commentary. I wouldn't say its too bad, but I know there are parents out there who don't like cursing. Other than enjoy.

reviewText: I remember ren and stimpy back in the 90's on tv, catching it on tv was rare but awesome.Needless to say, when i found it for sale on here i went for it. The prices it was at seemed worth it, but I have to admit there were things I guess i just didnt pay attention to back then.I cant for the life of me remember the animation being so stock. colours quite blotched and dull, but I guess that adds to the charm of it.All these classic episodes still get the laughs out of me. I guess its one of those collectables which I will hold onto for a while, but I dont really see myself watching it all that much more then once.Passed it onto friends, they had the same feeling about it. Awesome yet they also forgot about how stock it was, I blame new CG in movies, new gen animation (ala pixar) and the death of 2D cartoons (mind you, the simpsons still rule that domain).Good to remind you of lesser stressful times and being care free. Definatly a happy happy happy purchase!

reviewText: There's barely anything important missing here.Why would they have it be that way, anyway unless there had been some kind of accident/originals being destroyed by Nick?And if John Kricfalusi considers it "uncut" then maybe this is what's uncut and a finished product to him!Anything "missing" can easily be found (in very low quality).This has always been one of my absolute favourite television shows ever, because it matches exactly the kind of disturbing humour that so oft causes me to be misunderstood...And giggle about it!So don't listen to those who will sit out in the cold while the gorgeously mastered versions sit on the shelves, rejected by snobby hands.Pick it up and clutch it to your bosom and cry....HAPPY HAPPY!!....JOY JOY!!.end.

reviewText: There's not much missing here - I don't know what the fuss is about.  I realize that true maniacal fans will only be satisfied with perfection, but this is a really good set.  The transfers are good with decent extras, the important stuff has been added back in after Nick butchered some episodes, there's just not a lot to complain about.I've been waiting ten freakin' years for this to come out.  I bought it and I'm happy as hell to be watching Ren and Stimpy again.  Good luck to the ones that are holding out for the "perfect" set - I think you'll be waiting a long, long time.  Perhaps I'll be the one with egg on my face (first edition South Park DVD's, anyone?), but I doubt it.

reviewText: I'm sure even Dr. Stupid would agree that it was a bad idea to call this set UNCUT.  It is mesleading to put the word "uncut" in large type on the cover of the set when every episode is not uncut.That said, some episodes are completly uncut and are labeled as such.  If you know this before buying, you come to it with open eyes and there is no need to get upset.  Sure, I want every episode uncut, but that's not what this set is.  And frankly I'm so glad to have them in high quality (for the most part - some episodes are noticably grainy) and the illuminating bonus material that it doesn't matter.For new commers to Ren & Stimpy you are in for a real treat.  Many of the story ideas and elements feel as if they came to this planet from some far off galaxy.  Shaven yacks?  Magic Nose Goblins?  A super hero made of powdered toast?  Yes, they do exist and can all be found on this set with many more outragous characters and situations.Also on this set is the never aired "Man's Best Friend" pilot.  The set lists the episode as on disc 3 but it actually appears on dics 2.  Frankly I wasn't that impressed with the show, but was cool to finally see where the segments for the opening credits came from.To date, this is the best presentation of Ren & Stimpy offered.  All fans should pick it up (despite the few edits) and new viewers will marvel at the sureal world and unbelievable characters of Ren & Stimpy.

reviewText: There's been a long history of footage that has been cut from Ren & Stimpy. Some footage still might not exist. Some do like the line "Bring the kids next time you hear" at the end of the hanging song from Out West which is NOT included in this DVD. There were more pencil tests but it didn't make it to the DVD release. There's a website called "The Ultimute Spumco Ren & Stimpy Archive" or something like that, it's no longer on the internet but you can still find it on a links page to old Ren & Stimpy sites and go onto archive.org and see it, according to the site, there was a bunch of stuff cut out of Stimpy's Invention and the other early episodes.Other then that, It's a pretty good set of the original Spumco Ren & Stimpy. There are unnecessary fade to black transitions in a few episodes just because those masters were made when the reruns where shown on Spike TV and not from the original masters, even though it does say at the beginning "digitally remastered".The commentaries are interesting though not on every episode, and not much information about the banned episode "Man's Best Friend" featuring George Liquor which along with John K missing due dates was the reason why he got fired and a few of his employees were to join Nickelodeon for Games Animations to continue the show without him.Still, it's a good box set, but someday let it be re released UNCUT! With more special features.
summary: It's not really Uncut, it's Cut
Title: N/A

reviewText: I bought this set before I read all the negativity here on the Amazon review board. Now, being a VERY PICKY person, myself, I still find this DVD set to be worth purchasing. I am a little upset that some scenes are left out but the picture quality and sound are superb. I am viewing them on a 36" HDTV and I see no pixelization whatsoever. The colors are very vibrant and make the cartoons look brand new, which is why I bought the DVD in the first place, not to mention getting them in the archival format. I'm afraid that if so many people harp with this negative campaign, there will be no more DVD releases for R&S. Often, such complaints result in just the opposite reaction one would expect. I would like to own the entire series, eventually and am very happy and greatful that the first two seasons are now in my DVD collection. I do, however, agree that the word "uncut" should be removed from the packaging. Editing is often a problem with programs that have been around a long time but it's no excuse for blatant false advertising. Someone, somewhere still has the original uncut masters and that is what we, the customers, expect from a "complete, uncut" collection of shows. With all that said, I still rate this collection to be five stars, just because it's 300% better than what I had before.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Now I am upset about the blatant false advertising concerning the "Uncut" episodes as much as the rest of you are.  I recently sold my Time Life DVD's on eBay thinking that I was FINALLY getting the original "Uncut" versions.  Now before we all go filling a class-action lawsuit against Paramount, Nickelodeon or Spike, take into consideration that we ARE at least getting the unaired episode of Man's Best Friend (at last I can throw away my crappy Nth generation VHS copy) so technically it is somewhat "Uncut."  As for episodes like "Powdered Toastman" and the censoring of PTM's burning of the U.S. Constitution and the removal of the cross on Frank Zappa's hat... well, you can blame Nick for that.Here is the FINAL word regarding the edits to the alleged (UNCUT) DVD versions directly from creator John Kricfalusi that was posted on TVshowsonDVD.com:"Hey folksI'm as surprised as you are that there are still some edits in the cartoons. Blame Nickelodeon years ago! Don't blame the producers of the DVD.We put back every scene that I was aware was missing. Nick must have cut more scenes out long after I stopped watching the show.But, we put a lot of cool stuff back in that no one ever saw-scenes from Sven Hoek that never aired-George Liquor's bobbed tail in Dog Show-hey all of Man's Best Friend!We also did lots of commentaries over the cartoons and there are interviews with me and Eddie Fitzgerald, there is original artwork.Buy this damn thing. I put in as much cool stuff as I could for you. Buy it and maybe Spike will order new episodes!Maybe I will consult with you to restore the episodes you found that still has cuts and we'll put the missing scenes on a website for you, or run them ouncut on Spkie.If every show is not completely intact it's because long ago Nick misplaced or lost the originals, but I restored the ones I knew had cuts, ok?So if you review the set on Amazon, say it's great and and talk about the good stuff first! Then you can mention that there are still some edits, but it's definitely worth getting!Maybe we can have a chat about it tomorrow night if someone contacts me to set it up.Your pal,John K."Heh... well, this all sounds like a marketing ploy to get us to purchase THESE versions until an ULTIMATE, UNCUT & UNCENSORED box set is offered.  John K., love ya man, but the fans are tired of getting raked over the coals when it comes to upgrading their DVD collections.  I supported you on the Time Life versions and look what it got me. Okay John, I will go ahead and say it is "Great" for the sake of this great series because it is definitely worth having, but I still feel like I've been suckered into buying yet another pair of pointless Rubber Nipples.  To quote Mr. Horse, "No Sir, I don't like it!"

reviewText: Even though this package claims to offer all the original Ren & Stimpy episodes in completely uncut form, you can clearly see from some of the more loudmouthed reviews here that this is not the case. Crybaby obsessives can rant and rave about that all they want, because 33 year-olds who live in their mothers' basements don't have any other problems in the world. The rest of us who love great entertainment can still dig this package. You may remember from back in the early 90s that the original batch of Ren & Stimpy cartoons on Nickelodeon were the sickest and most cracked pieces of animation ever seen, with brutally fast-paced and eccentric humor from the sick mind of John Kricfalusi. The most classic shorts are here on disc one, including my personal favorites "Nurse Stimpy" and "Space Madness."After the initial small batch of episodes became cult classics back in the day, Ren & Stimpy had trouble maintaining the same level of sick humor. Starting on disc two here the series becomes very inconsistent, and sometimes downright unfunny, as the gross-outs and insanity cease to deliver many real laughs. There are a couple of later gems like "Big Baby Scam" and "Dog Show." But unfortunately this package slows down with clunkers like the hugely overrated "Sven Hoek" in which sheer stupidity stops being funny, or the painfully slow and poorly produced "Powdered Toast Man." Late installments like "Stimpy's Fan Club" and "Visit to Anthony" are barely even humorous at all. Here we can see that Ren & Stimpy started out absolutely brilliant but failed to keep up with that initial burst of hysteria. Of course, this is still a valuable DVD package for those who love cutting-edge humor, and those early classics are more than worth the price of admission. But you'll find that the absence of a few deleted scenes here and there is hardly the end of the world. (...)

reviewText: I bought the set before reading the reviews here, and was a little worried that I might have wasted my money. All in all, I don't agree with any assessments about poor picture quality, the colors look great; the only episode with video artifacts I noticed was the original "Big House Blues," but that contains the waking up scene that I had never seen.Yes, I compared "Big Baby Scam" to my old video tape pulled from a Nick broadcast. Why the whistling is missing is beyond me; someone to claim that this was a Spike edit to allow additional commercials is ludicrous as that scene amounts to not much more than 5 seconds. Maybe it was a legitimate error and will be corrected in a later DVD pressing, I don't know.My disc 3 had digital errors and refused to track properly at 20 minutes; I'm hoping a replacement solves that problem.All in all, a good collection, still worth seeking out unless you're a complete eeediot.
summary: Slightly cut, yes, but good nonetheless
Title: N/A

reviewText: Ah, to be a kid again, growing up in the early '90s. I remember every Saturday night, at 9:30 PM, my parents had to stop whatever they were doing, so I could run out and watch my favorite show, Ren & Stimpy. All these classic episodes, which Nickelodeon would NEVER show now (Hard to believe the same network that showed this as recent as a decade ago now specializes in crapola such as All Grown Up... ugh)... they're now on DVD - with restored cuts! Happy happy, joy joy!So how does this DVD set measure up? Well, pretty damn well, I have to say. It's definitely a step up from the old VHS tapes I had recorded years ago... the sound is good, the picture is good, and we get the classics, such as "Space Madness", "Stimpy's Invention", "Sven Hoek", "Stimpy's Big Day/The Big Shot", et cetera, not to mention the "banned" episode, "Man's Best Friend". What more could you want?If you remember the good old days where kids shows didn't have to be politically correct (can someone please explain Dora the Explorer?!?!?), and instead of kid's shows having kids force-fed another language, they showed the wacky, goofy adventures of a short-fused chihuahua and a fat, dopey cat, then definitely get this boxed set. It's great to slap "The Fairly Oddparents" in the face with! Now get Rocko's Modern Life, Tiny Toon Adventures, and Old Doug on DVD box sets and I'll be a happy camper.And, IMHO, Ren's insane laugh while cleaning Stimpy's litter box in "Stimpy's Invention" is the best 30 seconds in the show's history.
summary: "SEE HOW I LOVE TO CLEAN FEELTHY CAT BOXES!!!"

reviewText: Until the almost shocking official release of Ren & Stimpy cartoons ("Big House Blues" toured with the Spike & Mike cartoon festival before the Nickelodeon days) the short form animated cartoon medium seemed hopelessly slumped. Then finally, in came a cartoon not made from cardboard cutouts with facial and bodily expressions that defied description. The characters had an amorphisity to them that seemed limitless (a real life Stimpy would be full of goo). Add to this multifarious variations on the voices, variations on the characters, variations in pacing, and an amazing use of classical and modern music. Then throw in lots of non-kiddie oriented humor and disgusting visuals (boogers appear more than once in the series) and what do you get? An all out assault on the cartoon centers of the human brain. It was blindingly obvious that someone took these toons very serious.It's been a long long long wait since the VHS days. Much too long. Then, like a ten year stifled breath suddenly released this DVD set appeared. It includes all the greats: Big House Blues (in both the "uncut" version and the Nickelodeon version), Stimpy's Big Day (with Muddy Mudskipper), Space Madness, Marooned (would give any kid under ten permanent nightmares), Stimpy's Invention ("Happy Happy Joy Joy"), Rubber Nipple Salesman (one of the most twisted toons ever), In the Army, Out West, The Royal Canadian Kilted Yaksmen (runs a tight second for the most twisted toon ever). Not only these works of mad cartoon art, but also interviews with John K., audio commentary and animated menus that preserve the soul of the show. Another nice touch was keeping the actual Nickelodeon shows intact. All of the original segueways, titles, and credits seep from the bits (i.e., "Ask Doctor Stupid, the variations on "Log", etc.). So watching this set mirrors watching the show as it was back in the early 1990's (though some have complained of missing parts here and there). Of course this makes scanning directly to a toon a little inconvenient (the chapters are by episode, not by isolated toons). So it's not perfect, but whatever flaws the set itself may possess, they get offset by the exaulting joy of finally having these toons available on DVD. It's been too long. Much much much too long.The second set will likely be full of episodes directed by Bob Camp. Bob more or less took the series over after John K had a "falling out" with Nickelodeon. The series lived on afterwards, but eventually pittered out almost without a squeak. John K. started Spumco (whose website appears long gone as of this writing), released comic books, and produced an internet animation for Quisp cereal (very much worth a look). Though John K's still around - somewhere - this set represents his peak toon output to date. Any fan of the ridiculous and surreal will bask lovingly in its tasty absurdity. Cartoonists seeking inspiration (particularily visual) will find it here. A valuable addition to the DVD world.
summary: The rebirth of cartoons in the 1990s...

reviewText: It really is nice to see this series again. I've been a huge fan of this series ever since it first aired and it feels really good to have the first two seasons in my DVD collection.The extras on this DVD are very good. I particularly like the "In the Beginning" documentary that gives a brief history of how the show got started and the characters designs and how they came up with the characters.The only thing that bugged me about this collection is that we got the Spike TV versions, and the forced commercial breaks became irritating over time. In the middle of a scene, it goes black screen and then cuts back on and continues to finish the scene. They should have taken the commercial "black outs" out.  That's my main gripe about this DVD. Besides that, I really do like it and look forward to them releasing the third and fourth season this year, hopefully.
summary: I'd Love It If It Weren't For The Stupid Black Outs!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Most people by now are aware of the protracted battle between John Kricfalusi (John K.) and Vanessa Coffey at Nick. The result was the shocking revelation that Nick/ MTV Networks/ Viacom could legally keep the titles and characters of Ren and Stimpy while firing John K. from the show. Later seasons were left to his fellow writer Bob Camp and in the opinion of many viewers, go downhill fast. This first season, however, was/ is ground-breaking in many ways, as wonderfully revisited on this DVD set.It's not exactly uncut, as other reviewers have noted. What it is is restored, which is to say that John K. put back as much as he could find/ remember from the original shows. I watched all the still cut out bits when R and S ran on Nick, but they may have been edited out as with reruns of The Simpsons to make room for ever more commercials in the TV line-up.Ren and Stimpy is often regarded as an envelope-pushing cartoon, and someone even wrote a book saying John K. pushed it as far as the market would bear (or farther). What viewers notice and critics overlook is his canny historical sense. Like Scott Shaw, John K. is a fan of early Hanna-Barbera 'toons and duplicates the look here and there. Not to mention the "takes" of Tex Avery. R and S was quite an achievement. The titles are entirely taken from one show "Fire Dogs" but it doesn't look like it (creative use of a pilot show). Innuendo was relatively tasteful in this almost for kids version (and many adults would be fine with their kids watching season one, myself included).The upshot of the animation war was that there is a new respect for writers and animators in the cartoon arena, better contracts and more emphasis on creator's rights. John K., always the rebel, named his company Spumco after Raymond Spum, the only man to ever fire Walt Disney. Walt swore he'd erase Spum's name from the annals of animation history, and John K. as we have seen, brought it back.The many viewers of Family Guy and Cartoon Network's adult swim block will have no trouble with Ren and Stimpy, but I'd like to counteract the warnings on the DVD box. Season one is not to be missed, and I would urge animation fans to pick up this box set. Later seasons go downhill primarily due to Bob Camp's overkill heavy-handedness, which also happened with his writing for Space Goofs, a great concept that got buried under unsubtle writing. Compare these relatively innocent R and S shows to the unrestrained "adult" version on Spike TV and see how much better these "restrained" shows are. How about bringing back some great-written shows like Savage Steve Holland's Eek the Cat or DIC's Little Shop cartoon (spun off from Little Shop of Horrors)? Why don't studios bring these out on DVD? That's just one of my many questions to ask Dr. Stupid.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Sadly, the reviews people have been sending in lately are true, more than half of the episodes have gaps in them for Spike TV commercials (the set was funded by Spike TV by the way, a viacom company) or are missing in between segments. here is the breakdown for the real hardcores, and believe us John K., there are a lot of us.32 shorts broken into 18 episodes with assorted inbetween cartoons. The inbetween cartoons were all unaltered, although I did notice that one of the ending segments where Ren and Stimpy say goodbye was missing.21 shorts with commercial gaps:Stimpy's Big Day, The Big Shot, Robin Hoek, Nurse Stimpy, Space Madness, The Boy Who Cried Rat, Marooned, Untamed World (A Cartoon), Black Hole, Stimpy's Invention, Ren's Toothache, Rubber Nipple Salesman, Haunted House, Mad Dog Hoek, Dog Show, Man's Best Friend, The Great Outdoors, The Cat That Laid the Golden Hairball, A Visit to Anthony, The Royal Canadian Kilted Yaksmen, and Son of Stimpy (Stimpy's First Fart)8 shorts that are original Nickelodeon cuts, no gaps:Fire Dogs, The Littlest Giant, In the Army, Monkey See Monkey Don't, Powdered Toast Man, Fake Dad, Out West, and Stimpy's Fan Club2 shorts absolutely uncut:Sven Hoek and Big House Blues1 short with scene missing:Big Baby ScamMost of the shorts with commercial gaps pick up right where they left off, so it's no big deal, but some shorts lose a couple of seconds, so that may rub some viewers who have seen these a couple of times and recognize this as modern art the wrong way. Big Baby Scam, however, loses an entire scene due to the fact that it was placed together with the longer short, Dog Show, which was a rarely seen gem before Spike started with the reruns.The bonus features are okay. I figure for those of you who won't buy this for the cuts and whatnot, I will tell you that the one real special feature, an interview with John K., wasn't that special. He tells us that Ren's voice is a knock off Peter Lorre impersonation and that Stimpy's is Larry from the Three Stooges. He also kind of dismisses the connotations that Ren and Stimpy are gay. I understand his point of view, he didn't want to make gay fans mad by saying no, so he skirted it.Final note, the 10 shorts that are unaltered are worth buying this set. The gaps aren't that big a deal, but as a huge fan from the age of ten, they are to me.

reviewText: Simply stated, Ren and Stimpy seasons 1 and 2 were classics in every sense of the word. In those two seasons, John Kricfalusi re-invented the entire cartoon genre. He did this by going back to basics, following the spirit of the great cartoons of the 40s and 50s.Ren & Stimpy were REAL cartoons, not like the "Animated Sitcoms" that people often confuse with a cartoon. The differences are black and white. Unlike today's bland world of animation, where there are limits to what can happen, a REAL cartoon like R&S; has no limits. Gravity in a cartoon is optional (it generally vanishes when you don't look down). It also means that characters can explode, shrink, be shaved bald, eat fire, spit fire and even shoot fire out their rear end.Seasons 1 and 2 were exceptionally good because those seasons were finely crafted by the mind of the show's creator, John Kricfalusi. In subsequent seasons, he was given more and more pressure to censor the content. As time went on, he eventually lost his battle (and his job), and the network cranked out a bunch of sterile cartoons with no heart and soul.Last year, Time/Life attempted to put out a set of DVDs containing 42 or so episodes. The quality was crisp and clear, but the set was still censored and unfortunately it had production problems and was hard to get... eventually it vanished.Buy this set while you still can. If history repeats itself, these may not be out too long.
summary: They're back... Happy ... Happy ... Joy ... Joy!

reviewText: For all those complaining about cut scenes from this collection - John K. is currently developing a new "Ultimate" box set that will contain every single episode of "Ren & Stimpy," totally uncut, along with the entire "Adult Party" episodes from 2003 (advertised as "The Lost Episodes" on its initial DVD release).I don't feel like I wasted much by buying this - it was only $30 and a few cut scenes don't bother me much considering they also ADDED stuff to a lot of episodes - but if they're releasing a new box set soon I think I'll hold off on the other season releases that are out now and just save my money for the Ultimate DVD.Oh, and if you look hard enough, John K. has a link to early artwork for the new box set on his website - it looks pretty cool, too.

reviewText: Even with the few things that are missing (most notably the Bloody Head Fairy in "Haunted House") this DVD set really is a must have for Ren & Stimpy fans.In addition to the "banned" episode "Man's Best Friend" and uncut versions of "Big House Blues" and "Powdered Toastman" there are six interesting and even funny commentaries. Plus you're getting 32 episodes of some of the funniest, most outrageous cartoons ever put on TV.Ren & Stimpy was a landmark, and all us people who like funny moving pictures should remember that. Do I wish that every second and every frame were here? Yup, I sure do. But there really isn't much missing. A few seconds here and there mostly (Go down to the review titled "Time to set things straight" by Joshua Smith for a complete rundown of the missing footage, and be sure to give him a helpful vote too, while you're at it).And I swear the cartoons just get funnier the more you watch them.  So, just buy the danged thing.  You won't be sorry.
summary: That's right, no Bloody Head Fairy but . . .
Title: N/A

reviewText: One of the very first cartoons featuring crude, gross-out comedy is finally here on DVD, and I'm glad.  The Ren & Stimpy Show has quite a following.  It was the first time (to my knowledge) a cartoon surprised and amused audiences with outrageous content people weren't used to seeing on TV.  It was fresh.  It was creative.  It was done with style.Ren's reactions to what life throws at him remind me so much of myself.  That's a character I can identify with, and that contributes heavily to my fondness of the series.  I suspect most of Ren & Stimpy's fans can relate to some character on the show.When you think about it, the personalities of these two are deep!  What other character combines such caring regard for others with utter stupidity like Stimpy?  Insanity-prone Ren personifies the struggle we all experience in coping with daily events.  The behavior of Ren & Stimpy is fun to behold.Now, with all that being said, I don't feel like The Ren & Stimpy Show has aged perfectly.  After viewing the DVDs I have to say the show isn't quite as funny as I remember it.  Maybe my disappointment is due to my evolved tastes, or me being used to such humor thanks to so many similar shows since then, I don't know.  It's still funny, it just didn't make me laugh as much as it did in the early 1990's.I'm a little concerned about what I'm hearing from other reviewers about this collection not being truly uncut...that some of the episodes still lack certain footage and have been edited. Completeness is important to me, and I don't like the idea of my Ren & Stimpy set missing something.  Until I heard about this, though, I was content with the DVDs.  The episodes sure look complete to me, so I think I can live with it.
summary: The Original Animated Low-Brow Humor Duo

reviewText: I think a reason for the widespread criticism of the "Ren & Stimpy" DVD set is this: "Ren & Stimpy" was such an incredibly great cartoon show that it impressed so many viewers so strongly that every phrase, every picture was highly memorable.  That, along with LOTS of reruns, make it noticeable when anything is edited out in subsequent viewings.  DVD releases of motion pictures and television series are expected to be permanent, definitive versions, which in many peoples' minds includes having every original scene.  The fact that a handful of cartoons on this DVD set are acknowledged to have been edited and have numerous fade-outs where additional commercial breaks were added in later TV reruns, makes this DVD set flawed and disappointingly so.The edits don't stop the cartoons from still being howlingly funny and I have no problem with picture and sound quality.  The bonus features are all welcome.Still, I hesitate to give this DVD set my highest praise.  "Ren & Stimpy", along with "The Simpsons", were the finest animated cartoons of the 1990s and brought life back into a form of entertainment that had been in a creative low period for far too long.  It is too bad this DVD set is marked with flaws.  Inattention to detail is the culprit here.My suggestion is that the five cartoons on this DVD set with missing scenes be released without any missing scenes as bonus features on the Season 3 DVD set.  That would satisfy me.
summary: edits & fade-outs flaw DVD set of superb series
Title: N/A

reviewText: Alright, alright, so maybe some minor edits were still prevelant in some of the episodes. We can go back and forth on who to blame: John K, Nickelodeon, Viacom, Spike TV, Paramount... But, c'mon. Only ONE actual scene was fully cut (from "Haunted House"), and all the other cuts are really quick and stupid (from "Big Baby Scam"). A lot of reviews have talked about false advertising, wanting "UNCUT" removed from the box. OK, maybe it is untrue, since four or five episodes have cuts in them, but along with those are the other twenty+ ones that are completely restorted and uncut, like "Sven Hoek" and "Powdered Toast Man." Maybe Paramount will do what Universal did with the messed up Back to the Future II and III DVDs and release a statement to send discs 2 and 3 back to them and they'll send back uncut versions of the episodes... but I doubt it. But for now, this is the best "Ren and Stimpy" collection we've got, and we shouldn't whine too much about it. I might not be a rabid "Ren and Stimpy" fan, but I do enjoy the show, and this DVD. And I immensely enjoy the previously unseen "Man's Best Friend," and to clear up what many previous reviewers have been puzzling about, even though it's listed as being on disc 3, it's actually under the bonus features on disc 2.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Nickelodeon used to have some fantastic cartoons on television back in the 90's. Yet, they some how have forgotten about some of their classics. From Rocko's Modern Life, to surprising revivals like Doug, and Rugrats, none was ever a cult classic like Ren & Stimpy. Back in the 90's, they were just one of the zaniest duos of all time. The taleless cat, Stimpy, and his nutty-crazed dog pal Ren, recently scored a cult-comeback on the Spike! network last year. While the new shows might be fresh and silly, nothing ever compare to the classic episodes that made Ren & Stimpy household names.Ren & Stimpy: The Complete First & Second Seasons, brings a whole new generation into the zany madness Ren & Stimpy have been in. The cartoons are truly classic, and still have a bit of splice. So many great favorites are on here including Stimpy's Invention, which made people go nuts with the Happy, Happy, Joy, Joy! song, Big House Blues, one of the very first ever episodes, as well as a few bonuses like the recently unveiled episode Man's Best Friend on Spike!, and other goofy additons. While this might be great for new fans, older fans of Ren & Stimpy are going to be a bit dissapointed with the collection. Most of them might be saddened with some of the episodes not released in the original format, and may consider passing this one up. Especially with some scenes removed like in Ren's Toothache, Stimpy's constant flossing and brushing in the beginning is not included, where recent DVD packages like Looney Tunes: The Golden Collection brilliantly restored all the features, and the unedited laughter to match.All in all, Ren & Stimpy: The Complete First & Second fairs well for anybody who actually hasn't seen the one time Nickelodeon duo in action, but others might want to glance at the recent Complete Third and a halffish package to see if nothing was removed from there, or just wait for a better Ren & Stimpy package to boot.Cover: BPrice: B+Mastering: B-Extras: BOverall: B 1/2+

reviewText: I mainly bought it because I love Ren and Stimpy. I grew up with the show, and after so long, it's been my #1 favorite cartoon, next in line with FAMILY GUY, SIMPSONS, SOUTH PARK, AND FUTURAMA.I'll have to admit this isn't the best box set out there, mainly because 4 minutes worth of material were left out, but it's close enough. And luckily, the episodes that were cut are not on my personal favorite list.I even showed the set to my 9-year-old and 11-year-old brothers, and they weren't complaining; and also showed it to my uncle (who's been a fan of the show since he loves warped humor), who's always wanted to see the unedited version of BIG HOUSE BLUES--And sure enough, after seeing it he plans on buying the set.Of course, what I like best about this set is that rarely seen additional footage was added to my two personal favorites: SVEN HOEK, and BIG HOUSE BLUES. Also, the banned episode MAN'S BEST FRIEND (which was only aired twice on SpikeTV) is included as a bonus episode on disc two and has become another of my personal favorites; Ren beating the living snot out of George Liquor with an oar was a real hoot.Plus the video and audio quality is great. The video has an almost clear picture (with some dust) and bright colors; and for audio we have a Dolby English Stereo track with very strong sound.Finally, the extras are good. First, we have a 12-minute documentary on how the show began called "Ren & Stimpy: In the Beginning". Next, we have a couple more featurettes like the "Sven Hoek Pencil Test" and a "Storyboards and Spumco Image Gallery". And what box set could be complete without interesting Audio Commentaries on 6 episodes (mostly led by John K. and Eddie Fitzgerald)? Finally, there's one Easter Egg: a commentary on MAN'S BEST FRIEND by Spumco employee Eddie Fitzgerald.Anyway, if you love this show, this is a must-own. If you already heard the cuts being made, this won't change your mind, believe me-I still craved to get the set and I found it on sale for $25. So buy the set while you can.Plus, I hope they'll make a "best of" DVD with the cut episodes in their original uncensored form.
summary: Definitely "Collector's Edition", regardless of the cuts.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I haven't stopped leaping around and screaming like an annebriated cheerleader since I found out about this DVD release.  SO many years of waiting, hoping, and wishing that SOMEBODY would come to their senses and commit the bright shining orb of comic brilliance that is the Ren & Stimpy Show to a digital format for posterity's sake where it belongs!!!  Here it is, folks.  The show that made an entire nation remember how great a cartoon could be without safe, watered-down characters and bland, uninteresting storylines.  THIS is the show that put non-offensive, unimaginative and parent-friendly fluff like Scooby Doo on the back-burner once and for all.  I'll bet that when this thing sells about twelve-gozillion units, the critics who call this show obscene, sophomoric, and needlessly violent (which is what people with a sense of humor LOVE about cartoons in the first place!) will all be forced to stick their feet in their mouths just where they belong.  I of course haven't seen the DVD yet, but I've seen all of these episodes (happy memories from my childhood, when Nickelodeon gave a hoot) and I already know that this will be the most eagerly anticipated and joyous addition to my DVD library this year!!!  All hail Ren & Stimpy!!!

reviewText: Definitely don't eat breakfast cereal while watching these episodes - a corn flake might surge into your sinus cavity and be propelled out of your nose from convulsive, involuntary laughter.Ren & Stimpy are a cartoon classic, etched permanently into America's (sub)culture."My prize collection of rare and exotic diseases -- VIOLATED!!""WHATEVER YOU DO, DON'T TOUCH THE RED BUTTON""Daaah, I yam Awlie He is Sven ...(?)""This wiiill hurrrrt Youuu""They're filled with glue!!""Next time keep your stinkiness to yourself."And, of course, "YOU EEEEDiot, You feelthy, Bloated SACK!! I'm going to KEEEEEEL YOU!!!"Powdered Toast Man's method of propulsion is obscenely juvenile and, indeed, Ren's soapy sponge bath ending up on Page 1 of the newspaper is pretty much third grade stuff.  The rubber nipple salesman episode doesn't rank up there on the maturity scale, either.So what?Stimpy's moronic expressions - alone - are worth the price of this CD.On the Laugh-O-Meter (guffaws per minute), you can't beat Ren & Stimpy.  I can imagine the animators falling out of their chairs laughing at the insane idiocy they put to film.Do check it out.  Just not while chewing your wheaties.

reviewText: I have every episode from the first two seasons (the only two seasons) on VHS tape.  After reading enough of these reviews to know what is and isn't on the DVD set, and being the R&S purist that I am, I have decided to digitize my VHS tapes onto DVD and preserve the TRULY uncut versions of the original episodes for time and all eternity.  Some of you might remember when MTV ran their "Ren at Ten" marathon in 1992, when they played every single Ren & Stimpy episode ever made (including the "fart" episode) starting at 10PM every evening for several weeks.  I taped them all, and I'm making my own DVD set out of them.  Let this be a lesson to all - always tape your favorite shows with only the best quality tapes - it pays off in the long run, especially over a decade later (when most other tapes are giving out).  Digitizing R&S VHS tapes onto DVD is the only option that die-hard Ren & Stimpy purists like me have as an alternative.  Sorry, John K., but the best cartoon series in history deserves to be preserved in it's original form.  Too bad it's the fans who are going to do it and not you.  I'd also like to stress that there are laws in this country about false advertizing ("uncut").
summary: That's It - I'm Digitizing My Old "Uncut" VHS Tapes to DVD

reviewText: I didn't realize it at the time, but Ren & Stimpy quite possibly could be the BEST cartoon animation we've seen on television in the last 50 years. reviewText: Like so many others when Ren & Stimpy hit the airwaves in /91 I was immediately hooked with its' absolute off the wall and irreverant humour courtesy of its' driving force Mr.John Kricfalusi.He and his fellow workers at Spumco created an instant classic that hasn't lost any of its' appeal.This wonderful set contains the BEST that the series had to offer.However John K. was constantly having to dodge Nicklodeon bullets throughout the series run and eventually he got hit more than he was missed.Shortly into the second season we can see plain evidence in episodes such as "Stimpys' Fan Club" and " Visit to Anthonys" of Nicklodeons' control starting to take effect on the product,as the John K. touch is  absent and the characters go totally mainstream.The frenetically paced humour/cutting has disappeared and they are frankly VERY boring.The series would really never reach the heights it did again with one of the last eps in this set "The Royal Canadian Kilted Yaksmen".The series went like a steadily declining graph thereafter with ever deepening valleys and fewer peaks.John K. fed up with the running battles and Nickelodeons' non stop efforts to warp and sanitize the characters  eventually threw in the towel and left the show altogether.So if you are a fan of Ren & Stimpy or are new to the series I couldn't recommend a better set for you to purchase for this is the shows' finest hour....no question.

reviewText: Yes, I did know this set was edited before I purchased it and the reason I am writing this review is because this set has an average 4 star rating on Amazon. Pathetic. The classical piece playing in the background and the look of fearful despair on Stimpy's face was so priceless that I would just roll in laughter, hardly able to breathe.IT... IS... ALL... reviewText: While I personally will always cite creator John Kricfalusi (John K.) more for his classic remake of Mighty Mouse (1987), his 1991 series The Ren & Stimpy Show featuring high-strung chihuahua Ren Hoek and naive Stimpson J. Cat was just as cool. Ren & Stimpy was Nickelodeon's "signature toon" as much as Beavis & Butthead was for MTV - and rightfully so. The Ren & Stimpy Show featured a near-perfect blend of zany wit, retro visuals and over-the-top sight gags that scored with kids and adults. This set arguably represents the best of the series as they include all of original creator John K. episodes. Originally, the voices of Ren & Stimpy were supplied by John K. and Billy West, respectively. West went on to voice both characters for the remainder of the series run following John Kricfalusi's termination from the show due to conflicts with Nickelodeon in 1992. Last year, short-lived sets of edited Ren & Stimpy shorts were released directly through Time Life. With Time Life's rights expired, Paramount will finally release Ren and Stimpy - The (presumably)Complete 1st & 2nd Seasons on October 12th! Over 30 episodes will be present on this release:"Stimpy's Big Day", "The Big Shot", "Stimpy's Storybook Land: Robin Hoek", "Nurse Stimpy", "Space Madness", "The Boy Who Cried 'Rat!'", "Fire Dogs", "Stimpy's Storybook Land: The Littlest Giant", "Marooned", "Untamed World", "Black Hole", "Stimpy's Invention", "In the Army", "Powdered Toastman", "Ren's Toothache", "Big House Blues", "Out West", "Rubber Nipple Salesmen", "Sven Hoek", "Mad Dog Hoek"**, "Haunted House"**, "Big Baby Scam"**, "Dog Show", "Son of Stimpy"**, "Monkey See, Monkey Don't"**, "Fake Dad"**, "The Great Outdoors", "The Cat That Laid The Golden Hairball"**, "Stimpy's Fan Club"**, "A Visit to Anthony"**, and "The Royal Canadian Kilted Yaksmen"**.**These 10 episodes (as well as extras) weren't featured on the old Time Life discs.Features:"Ren & Stimpy: In The Beginning" FeaturetteAudio Commentary from the Original CreatorsImage GalleryAnd more!Joy!
summary: John K. Presents Ren & Stimpy's 1st & 2nd Seasons!

reviewText: I'm so excited that this DVD is coming out (and that I just stumbled over it).  Ren & Stimpy were/are great, and I feel set off a  wave of hilarious, bizarre animation that continues to this day (Aqua Teen Hunger Force, Sealab 2021, Invader Zim, Family Guy, etc).  Everything they did was surreal and disturbing, and the shows were all that much funnier for it.  I remember back in the early 90s the shows first coming out, and my friends and I rolling around in hysterics at what was actually being broadcast on national television.  One of the most spectacular and enduring of these episodes is the unparalleled "Space Madness," many times copied but never truly duplicated.  I can only hope this episode is there along with the rest, and perhaps a generous smattering of classic Ren & Stimpy commercials ("Don't Whiz on the Electric Fence" boardgame; "Log", etc).
